page.title: 12SUTTON HOO SITE
page.content: At{Sutton Hoo,}the richest treasure yet discovered on British soil was excavated in{1939.}An{Anglo_Saxon} ship, about 29m long and clinker_built, was used to hold a burial chamber. There were, however, no human remains, meaning that the whole affair was a{cenotaph.}So rich were the jewels and treasures discovered, that there is little doubt that it was for a{king. {} { The remains have told historians {much about the period, they include: a {musical instrument, a helmet, a {standard and thirty_seven coins _ the {latter were especially useful to {historians. The treasures are now in the British Museum, with replicas in the local museum in Ipswich.
